results.content: nice and straight forward information, loved the way of presenting the content.

results.content: Its a good course. I would have preferred videos being longer as many were less than 2 minutes. Course doesn't show you how to create a Typescript app, but rather  shows you the gotchas and comparisons between JavaScript and Typescript.
results.content_html: Its a good course. I would have preferred videos being longer as many were less than 2 minutes. Course doesn't show you how to create a Typescript app, but rather shows you the gotchas and comparisons between JavaScript and Typescript.

results.content: As a .net developer this great tutorial  really opened my eyes and got me into JS/TS fast track!
results.content_html: As a .net developer this great tutorial really opened my eyes and got me into JS/TS fast track!

results.content:
This instructor is like a wild horse that is running in all direction in a disordered way over the Gran Canyon.​

This is a common problem of very good tech-people: they can't explain in a didactical way what they know.​

Don't get me wrong. The contents are very good if you look at them like a list of tips & tricks. So, very informative.
results.content_html:

results.content:
I've been following Sahil's work for many years, reading his books, watching courses on Pluralsite, and even seen his live talks, and now on udemy he doesn't fail to deliver his message and content.

What I really like about this course is that Sahil demonstrates the majority of his points live-esque using an editor and he types code on the spot for his examples. This is far cry from the static code in slides approach, seen in other courses.

Sahil never misrepresents technology in his courses, so if you want a real understanding of why JavaScript is bad and Typescript is good, then look no further than this course. I'm new to node.js programming, but have been developing JavaScript for web sites for years, and after watching this course I now understand I was doing it wrong. Further, with TypeScript, I no longer have to worry about shooting myself in the foot with any new code I write.

I recommend that developers get familiar with VSCode before following along with this course - it's not required, but makes coding much easier.

results.content:
If you are already a JavaScript developer, you won't find interesting the first half of the course; you may learn some facts, but you won't get "really good".

In the second half of the course you will learn the basics of TypeScript and some Gulp. Don't expect to hear about tsd (commonly used tool to manage external .d.ts) or to setup a Node.js project based in TypeScript.

I'm European and I found instructor's accent easy to understand. In general, I found it useful but I think it could be better.
results.content_html:
If you are already a JavaScript developer, you won't find interesting the first half of the course; you may learn some facts, but you won't get "really good".

In the second half of the course you will learn the basics of TypeScript and some Gulp. Don't expect to hear about tsd (commonly used tool to manage external .d.ts) or to setup a Node.js project based in TypeScript.

I'm European and I found instructor's accent easy to understand. In general, I found it useful but I think it could be better.

results.content:
Very disappointed with the course content.

Most videos in the course are about 2-3 minutes long and the author doesn't really spend any time discussing any concept or why something works the way it works. For instance, the section of IIFE contains a single snippet of code and there's zero explanation. The same is true for most lessons in the tutorial. 

They just are in a hurry to complete the lessons.
results.content_html:

results.content: I'll now go and read Douglas Crockford's book "JavaScript: The Good Parts". This takes more time, but I might be better off. The course looks unedited. After a while the author's colloquial chatting and his trying to type faster than he actually is able to, hitting backspace all the time, just gets annoying.

After a while the author's colloquial chatting and his trying to type faster than he actually is able to, hitting backspace all the time, just gets annoying.

results.content: Sahil is as always presenting in a great manner. He knows what he is talking about, and is an engaging instructor.
results.content_html: Sahil is as always presenting in a great manner. He knows what he is talking about, and is an engaging instructor.

results.content: Very good introduction course to specific of programming with Typescript.
results.content_html: Very good introduction course to specific of programming with Typescript.

results.content:
I watched this course until I reached 39% and was for the first time ever (watching Udemy courses) disappointed.

I surely understand a joke hearing somebody saying "It's because Javascript hates me", but several times?
I never heard "it's because [Reason]". It could have been helpful to know that Javascript does something like type coercion or so.

But getting the values from an array with a for(var t in [1,2,3]) and then really expecting the values ??  Come on!
(https://developer.mozilla.org/de/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/for...in)

results.content: Sahil is an instructor from whom I have always learned something useful as I watch his lectures. Sahil can take very complex topics and make them easy to grasp and use.
results.content_html: Sahil is an instructor from whom I have always learned something useful as I watch his lectures. Sahil can take very complex topics and make them easy to grasp and use.

results.content: Sahil Malik is a well known expert in the development industry and he brings his knowledge and wisdom to Javascript in this excellent Udemy course. In easily accessible, kind of bite-sized chunks, Malik breaks down Javascript essentials and introduces you to TypeScript, Microsoft's very interesting and contemporary variant. I highly recommend this course either as a refresher for those with Javascript experience, or as a beginning-intermediate course for developers new to JS. Two thumbs up.
results.content_html: Sahil Malik is a well known expert in the development industry and he brings his knowledge and wisdom to Javascript in this excellent Udemy course. In easily accessible, kind of bite-sized chunks, Malik breaks down Javascript essentials and introduces you to TypeScript, Microsoft's very interesting and contemporary variant. I highly recommend this course either as a refresher for those with Javascript experience, or as a beginning-intermediate course for developers new to JS. Two thumbs up.
